column2: 2016: 24 Hour News: Paintings by Professor Mary Armstrong
column3:
Fine Arts Department at Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Library

"These paintings were made as meditations on war
column4: specifically the war in Iraq which began in March 2003. The slow
column5: inexorable march to war was unavoidable.  The White House started to beat the drums
column7: and the media related these events in the 24 hours a day news cycle. It became a toxic diatribe full of manipulation and despair. Then
column8: the images of torture taking place
column11: and sickened. The series of Paintings that comprise 24 Hour News grew out of those disclosures.  The terrible arrogance of our leaders seemed dangerously absurd as they expressed terrifyingly diabolical frivolity in the face of such cruelty and destruction. When Donald Rumsfeld said
column13: I knew we were doomed to endure the “farce of arrogance” in its most devastating and destructive power. Thus
column14: the somewhat unfathomable connection between humor
column15: Eros and violence came into the paintings What’s So Funny?.  The images of the tortured and humiliated bodies from the Abu Graib prison exposed the horrifying lack of protection and sanctity for the bodies of the captured and the victims.  Spine  and Half a Brain express that vulnerability. The Lap paintings were an exasperated attempt to put the female point of view into the picture. The Virgin Mary’s Lap
column16: which normally holds such love and tenderness
column17: now holds the wastes of war. With Launch the Virgin’s lap turns from gory reds to celestial blue
column18: symbolizing her removal from the carnage below."

column2:
2016: Nathaniel Hawthorne and Frederick Douglass: Texts and Contexts at Burns Library

Although they are rarely considered in relation to each other
column3: Nathaniel Hawthorne’s The Blithedale Romance (1852) and Frederick Douglass’ “The Heroic Slave” (1853) were released about six months apart by publishers located on the same block in downtown Boston. Beyond this
column4: both works were richly interwoven into the fabric of American social
column7: literary and cultural life. This exhibition
column8: which began in a Spring 2015 Advanced Topic English Seminar
column11: and periodicals from the Burns Library’s Boston Collection to explore several of these contexts.

in Life and Times of Frederick Douglass, Boston: De Wolfe and Fish, 1895

2016: Alumni Night at Hockey at Cadigan Alumni Center

The Boston College Alumni Association and the Varsity Club invite you to join us for Alumni Night at Men's Hockey on Saturday
column4: 2016. This special alumni reception will include traditional tailgate fare
column6: and much more! A cash bar will be provided.

column1: The reception at Cadigan Alumni Center will begin at 4:30 p.m.
column2: and the puck drops at 7:00 p.m. The cost is $35 for adults and $10 for children (under 12) for the reception and hockey ticket. If you already have tickets to the game
column3: the cost of the reception is $25 for adults and $5 for children (under 12). Special GOLD pricing is available for those who qualify!

column1: We expect tickets to sell out quickly
column2: so don't miss the opportunity to see your top-ranked Eagles take on UConn!

2016: Fight the Impostor Syndrome to Improve Your Confidence and Career Webinar at Online Webinar

Do you feel undeserving of your success? Do you worry that you’ll be exposed as a fraud? If so
column3: you may be struggling with the “impostor syndrome
column4: ” a term for the feelings of self-doubt and inadequacy many professionals face
column5: particularly as they reach higher levels of success. In this presentation you will learn common triggers of the “impostor syndrome
column6: ” as well as strategies to build your confidence and conquer these disruptive feelings.

column1: This webinar will teach you how to:
Understand the “impostor syndrome” and its effects on high-achieving professionals.
Identify common triggers of the syndrome in order to recognize the roots of your feelings.
Learn strategies for overcoming feelings of self-doubt and for increasing your confidence.

column2:
2016: Human Rights and Judicial Independence in Guatemala at McGuinn Hall

With Claudia Escobar
column3: former Guatemalan judge and current Scholar at Risk at Harvard University's Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study

column1: Ms. Escobar spoke publicly last year on the acute corruption in the judicial selection process in Guatemala
column2: which was part of a wave of popular revolt against the government that ultimately led to the arrest of the president and vice president of the country on corruption charges. As a result of her brave actions
column4: she received threats and was forced to relocate to the US with her family to seek refuge.

column2: she will speak how this corrupted process represses judicial independence
column3: which in turn feeds into the larger problem of corruption in the country
column4: and will discuss how it might be addressed.

column1: A light lunch to be served. RSVP required.

column2:
2016: Picosecond Spin Caloritronics at Higgins Hall

David Cahill
column3: Department of Materials Science and Engineering and Materials Research Laboratory

column1: Abstract: The coupling of spin and heat gives rise to new physical phenomena in nanoscale spin devices and new ways to manipulate local magnetization. This field of study is typically referred to as “spin caloritronics”. Our work in this field takes advantage of recent advances in the measurement and understanding of heat transport at the nanoscale using ultrafast lasers. We use a picosecond duration pump laser pulses as a source of heat and picosecond duration probe laser pulses to detect changes in temperature
column3: and spin transfer torque using a combination of time-domain thermoreflectance and time-resolved magneto-optic Kerr effect Our pump-probe optical methods enable us to change the temperature of ferromagnetic layers on a picosecond time-scale and generate enormous heat fluxes on the order of 100 GW m-2 that persist for ~30 ps.

column1: Thermally-driven ultrafast demagnetization of a perpendicular ferromagnet leads to spin accumulation in a normal metal and spin transfer torque in an in-plane ferromagnet. The data are well described by models of spin generation and transport based on differences and gradients of thermodynamic parameters.
The spin-dependent Seebeck effect of a perpendicular ferromagnetic layer converts a heat current into spin current
column2: which in turn can be used to exert a spin transfer torque (STT) on a second ferromagnetic layer with in-plane magnetization. Using a [Co
column3: Ni] multilayer as the source of spin
column4: an energy fluence of 4 J m-2 creates thermal STT sufficient to induce 1 % tilting of the magnetization of a 2 nm-thick CoFeB layer.

and Eight Crates of Vodka at Gasson Hall

Lowell Humanities Series Presents Lev Golinkin.

column1: Lev Golinkin is the author of A Backpack
column3: and Eight Crates of Vodka. Golinkin
column5: came to the US as a child refugee from the eastern Ukrainian city of Kharkov (now called Kharkiv) in 1990.  His op-eds and essays on the Ukraine crisis have appeared in The New York Times
column9: among others; he has been interviewed by WSJ Live and HuffPost Live.

2016: Prayer and Imagination: Praying in Times of Transition at Corcoran Commons

A presentation by Marina McCoy

column1: How does the use of the imagination function as part of our human capacities? How can we allow God to use our imaginations in times of change
column3: or transition? Imagery both Biblical and from our own experiences can help us to grow in times of change.

2016: Recreating Identity: The Arts and Crafts Movement in Ireland at Burns Library

The Arts and Crafts Movement that first emerged in England in the 1880s took on a distinctive character in Ireland
column3: where its aesthetic and social ideals coalesced around the drive to forge a new national identity. Craft and industrial societies were established under the movement’s aegis to promote handpress printing and bookbinding
column6: and other applied arts. This exhibition complements McMullen Museum’s spring show
column7: “The Arts and Crafts Movement: Making It Irish.”

2016: University Ethics: How Colleges Can Build and Benefit from a Culture of Ethics at 24 Quincy Rd.

James Keenan

column1: Stories about ethical issues at universities make headlines every day. From sexual violence to racial conflict
column2: from the treatment of adjuncts to cheating
column5: and administrators face countless ethical trials. And yet
column6: very few resources exist to assist universities in developing an ethical culture. University Ethics addresses this challenge and studies different facets of university life—including athletics

column1: Professional ethics are a key component of training for numerous other fields
column6: but there is no prescribed course of study for the academy. Professors and administrators are not trained in standards for evaluating papers
column9: or contracts. University Ethics not only examines the ethical problems that colleges face one by one but proposes creating an integrated culture of ethics university-wide that fosters the institution’s mission and community.

2016: The National Museum of Ireland and the Making of a National Collection at Burns Library

Presented by Dr. Raghnall O'Floinn

column1: Sponsored by the Boston College University Libraries in collaboration with the McMullen Museum of Art and the Center for Irish Programs

2015 marked the 125th anniversary of the opening of the National Museum of Ireland in 1890. This lecture will look at the events which led to the formation of the National Museum and its development as a national cultural institution down to the present day.

2016: The Arts and Crafts Movement: Making it Irish at Devlin Hall

During a year of commemoration of the 1916 Easter Rising
column3: this exhibition offers the first comprehensive examination of the Irish Art and Crafts movement. Like the more familiar Irish Literary Revival
column4: Arts and Crafts practice accompanied and shaped the visual imagination of the country’s transformation from colony to independent nation. As its centerpiece
column5: the exhibition introduces dazzling early medieval-influenced metalwork and embroidered textiles from University College Cork’s Honan Chapel. The collection of this ideologically charged masterpiece of Arts and Crafts achievement
column7: has never before traveled beyond Cork.

column1: The exhibition also features Wilhelmina Geddes’s and Harry Clarke’s stained glass panels that evoke a Celtic and early Christian past
column2: but gesture toward the innovative modernism characterizing the Literary Revival. Other objects on display include handcrafted furniture and metalwork
column4: and jewelry replicating early medieval metalwork. They illustrate both the widespread popular dissemination of Revivalist motifs and the philanthropic promotion of handicraft industries that initiated the Arts and Crafts movement in Ireland.

column1: Major lenders include the National Museum of Ireland
column2: National College of Art and Design

column3: contains essays by scholars from Ireland
column5: and North America. A digital guide to the exhibition has been produced by Joseph Nugent and students in his digital humanities course.

column2: the exhibition has been curated by Vera Kreilkamp and Diana Larsen in collaboration with Virginia Teehan (University College Cork) and underwritten by Boston College
column3: the Patrons of the McMullen Museum
column4: and an anonymous donor in honor of Colman Welby
column5: with transportation provided by Aer Lingus.

column4: National College of Art and Design

column5: and May 30. Docent tours on Sundays at 2:00 p.m. starting February 2

"These paintings were made as meditations on war

2016: The Arts and Crafts Movement: Making it Irish at Devlin Hall

During a year of commemoration of the 1916 Easter Rising
column3: this exhibition offers the first comprehensive examination of the Irish Art and Crafts movement. Like the more familiar Irish Literary Revival
column4: Arts and Crafts practice accompanied and shaped the visual imagination of the country’s transformation from colony to independent nation. As its centerpiece
column5: the exhibition introduces dazzling early medieval-influenced metalwork and embroidered textiles from University College Cork’s Honan Chapel. The collection of this ideologically charged masterpiece of Arts and Crafts achievement
column7: has never before traveled beyond Cork.

2016: The Treasure of Hispanic Catholicism: Latino/Hispanic Ministry in American Catholicism at Cadigan Alumni Center

American Catholicism welcomed the 21st century in the middle of a major demographic and cultural transformation driven largely by the fast-growing presence of Hispanics
column3: who presently constitute about half of all Catholics in the country. How does such transformation affect our commitments to Catholic ministry
column5: and theological reflection? This presentation reflects on the challenges and possibilities of being Catholic in the United States in an increasingly Hispanic Church.

column1: Marilœ Del Toro is an STM student
column2: and Hosffman Ospino is STM assistant professor of Hispanic ministry and religious education. Moderator
column3: Thomas H. Groome is director of The Church in the 21st Century Center.

2016: The Deans Series: Be Courageously Authentic at Cadigan Alumni Center

Your Jesuit education taught you the importance of being true to yourself and in that
column3: to be men and women for others.

column1: At BC you were surrounded by people and programs that helped support you and encourage you to be your best
column3: as years and decades go by
column5: and you may even find yourself feeling alone and lonely in your pursuit of a discerning and ethical life.

column1: This talk will focus on helping you determine what makes you truly authentic. Fr. Burns will explore what it means to be true both to yourself and to others
column2: as well as how you can find ways to incorporate virtues in your life to help you live consistently in harmony with yourself and with God. You will leave refreshed and emboldened to live your life more truly and fully

"These paintings were made as meditations on war
column4: specifically the war in Iraq which began in March 2003. The slow
column5: inexorable march to war was unavoidable.  The White House started to beat the drums
column7: and the media related these events in the 24 hours a day news cycle. It became a toxic diatribe full of manipulation and despair. Then
column8: the images of torture taking place
column11: and sickened. The series of Paintings that comprise 24 Hour News grew out of those disclosures.  The terrible arrogance of our leaders seemed dangerously absurd as they expressed terrifyingly diabolical frivolity in the face of such cruelty and destruction. When Donald Rumsfeld said
column13: I knew we were doomed to endure the “farce of arrogance” in its most devastating and destructive power. Thus
column14: the somewhat unfathomable connection between humor
column15: Eros and violence came into the paintings What’s So Funny?. Spine  and Half a Brain express that vulnerability. The Lap paintings were an exasperated attempt to put the female point of view into the picture. The Virgin Mary’s Lap
column16: which normally holds such love and tenderness
column17: now holds the wastes of war. With Launch the Virgin’s lap turns from gory reds to celestial blue
column18: symbolizing her removal from the carnage below."

column7: has never before traveled beyond Cork.

2016: Navigating Office Politics Webinar at Online Webinar

This presentation is designed for professionals at all levels who would like to better understand and navigate office politics.

column1: Are office politics holding you back? Are you unclear about how to exert political influence? Do you prefer to avoid politics altogether? Office politics are inevitable but the good news is you can learn to be more politically savvy. Join this webinar to learn key strategies on how to maximize your political influence to advance your career.
Learn what is meant by office politics and why politics are inevitable in any organization.
Recognize your political strengths and weaknesses.
Identify key strategies for boosting your political influence at work.

Ray Madoff

2016: The Stuff of Children's Playthings: Nathaniel Hawthorne's Greek Mythology at Gasson Hall

Professor Sheila Murnaghan
column3: Alfred Reginald Allen Memorial Professor of Greek

column2: A Wonder-Book for Girls and Boys (1851) and Tanglewood Tales (1853)
column3: Nathaniel Hawthorne transformed classical mythology into pleasure reading for children. As he retold the myths for a new audience
column4: he was clear about the need to suppress darker themes of sexuality and depravity that were present in the mind of the adult story-teller and in the books for adults that he was writing during the same period. This lecture will examine the rhetorical and visual strategies through which Hawthorne and some of his illustrators negotiated the intersection between childhood ignorance and adult knowledge.

Roughly one-third of younger adults now say they have no religious affiliation; but who are they and why aren’t they in church? What do they mean when they protest that they are “spiritual”? This presentation will examine the demographic
column5: and cultural trends and will ask what local communities of faith can do in response.

2016: A Rebellious Son? Jesus and His Mother at the Wedding in Cana (John 2) at Corcoran Commons

In the Gospel of John
column7: and the disciples are at a wedding in Cana
column10: while the celebrations are in full swing. When Jesus's mother points out the problem to her son
column12: he answers in a surprising way: "Woman
column13: what does this have to do with you and me?" This lecture looks closely at this exchange in the context of Jewish and Greco-Roman norms governing parent-child relationships
column14: and considers its role in the Gospel's overall presentation of Jesus.

column1: Adele Reinhartz is Corcoran Visiting Chair in Christian-Jewish Relations at Boston College

column18: a medical actor and an innkeeper. She lives with her husband

2016: Thy Will Be Done: The Function of Prayer in Mark's Gospel at Corcoran Commons

While Luke's Gospel is known as the "Gospel of prayer
column3:
prayer plays an important role in Mark's Gospel. Not only does Mark present Jesus as model pray-er, he also emphasizes the significance of prayer for the new family gathered around Jesus, those who are committed to doing God's will.

Thomas D. Stegman, S.J. is STM associate professor of New Testament and chair of the Ecclesiastical Faculty.

View on site |

2016: Colm Tóibín at Gasson Hall

Colm Tóibín is the author of eight novels
column3: including Brooklyn andNora Webster and two collections of stories
column4: Mothers and Sonsand The Empty Family. He has been three times shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize; his play The Testament of Mary was nominated for a Tony Award in 2013. His work has been translated into more than thirty languages. He is a Contributing Editor at the London Review of Books and Irene and Sidney B. Silverman Professor of Humanities at Columbia University.

column2: 2016: Linda Colley: Publishing the Word: Constitutions
column4:
and War in the Age of Revolutions at Gasson Hall

Linda Colley is a leading historian who specializes in Britain
column5: empire and nationalism. She is currently Shelby M.C. Davis 1958 Professor of History at Princeton University. She previously held Chairs in history at Yale University and the London School of Economics
column6: and she was the first woman Fellow of Christ’s College
column7: Cambridge University. Linda Colley’s books include In Defiance of Oligarchy: The Tory Party 1714-1760
column10: Empire and the World 1600-1850 and The Ordeal of Elizabeth Marsh: A Woman in World History
column11: which was named by The New York Times as one of the ten best books of the year. Her third book
column12: Britons: Forging the Nation 1707-1837won the Wolfson History Prize. Her work has been translated into ten languages. Her most recent book was the highly-acclaimed Acts of Union and Disunion
column13: which was based on a 15-part BBC Radio 4 series broadcast in January 2014 ahead of the Scottish Independence Referendum and which examines what has held the United Kingdom together—and what might drive it apart.

"These paintings were made as meditations on war

column8: the images of torture taking place

column13: I knew we were doomed to endure the “farce of arrogance” in its most devastating and destructive power. Thus
column14: the somewhat unfathomable connection between humor
column15: Eros and violence came into the paintings What’s So Funny?.  The images of the tortured and humiliated bodies from the Abu Graib prison exposed the horrifying lack of protection and sanctity for the bodies of the captured and the victims.  Spine  and Half a Brain express that vulnerability. The Lap paintings were an exasperated attempt to put the female point of view into the picture. The Virgin Mary’s Lap
column16: which normally holds such love and tenderness
column17: now holds the wastes of war. With Launch the Virgin’s lap turns from gory reds to celestial blue
column18: symbolizing her removal from the carnage below."

2016: "Blacks in Boston: Black ... and Immigrant" at Gasson Hall

ABOUT THE BLACKS IN BOSTON CONFERENCE

the African & African Diaspora Studies Program (AADS) revives its “Blacks in Boston” conference series. The theme for this one-day event is "Blacks in Boston: Black ... and Immigrant.” This theme is designed to engage current issues in the US immigration debate
column3: and to explore what black immigrants and immigration bring to this conversation. Working with a planning committee composed of BC faculty and administrators as well as local community organizations that serve immigrant populations and work for civil rights for residents in Boston and New England
column4: “Blacks in Boston: Black ... and Immigrant” encourages submissions on the following suggested topics:

column1: - Definitions of “black” in sending and receiving countries
- Citizenship and belonging for black Americans
- Making home – social and cultural contributions (Music
- Immigration as a black civil rights issue
- Waves of black immigration to Boston/New England/New England from the Caribbean
- Why immigrate? Why New England? (1965 Immigration Act
All proposal materials must be submitted by Thursday
To register for the conference please click here.
Please view the Call For Papers flyer here.

Religiosas y Laicos de Habla Hispana (completamente en español) at Theology and Ministry Library

Éste es un encuentro con uno de los pensadores más allegados al Papa Francisco desde sus años como obispo en Argentina. El P. Galli continúa siendo uno de los consejeros más cercanos del Papa y fue instrumental en la escritura del documento final de Aparecida. Los participantes tendrán la oportunidad de entrar en diálogo directo con el P. Galli. Sin costo alguno
column4: incluye almuerzo. Cupo limitado. Se recomienda inscribirse con anticipación.

column1: P. Carlo María Galli es teólogo argentino
column2: Profesor Ordinario Titular en la Facultad de Teología de la Pontificia Universidad Católica Argentina y Asesor teológico del Papa Francisco.

column3:
Notre Dame at McGuinn Hall

"Uncovering Latent Signals using Independent Component Analysis: Statistical Theory and Applications"

2016: Latin American Intellectual Roots of Pope Francis’s Pontificate at Cadigan Alumni Center

This lecture draws from Fr. Galli’s work as an Argentinian theologian working on various Latin American projects
column3: including his close collaboration with then Cardinal Bergolio in writing the concluding document of Aparecida
column4: the groundbreaking 2007 meeting of Latin American Bishops that mapped the most recent pastoral and theological vision for evangelization on the continent.  This reflection is a journey through the various intellectual
column7: including the centrality of the “Theology of the People
column8: ” that shaped the thought of Pope Francis over the years and today inspires important directions of his pontificate.

column1: Rev. Carlos Maria Galli is professor of theology at the Pontifical Catholic University of Argentina and advisor to Pope Francis.

2016: Prayer and Imagination: Implications for Christian Educators at McGuinn Hall

Fifth in the Center for Ignatian Spirituality series of presentations.

column1: Generations of Christians have become better able to find God within themselves and in the world around them thanks to their experiences with Ignatian prayer. Join us for this presentation in which we will explore how Christian educators can draw upon the power of Ignatian imagination in their teaching to facilitate integration in their students’ lives as well as a deeper encounter with God.

column3: Adjunct Faculty in the Philosophy Department at Boston College

2016: Poetry Days presents Afaa Michael Weaver at Devlin Hall

Despite the poverty and desperation that surrounded him in the East Baltimore neighborhood where he grew up
column3: Afaa Weaver has forged a life that his sharecropper father perhaps dreamed of for his son. Weaver began writing poetry about love and social justice while studying at the University of Maryland
column4: College Park. By the age of 27
column5: he was publishing consistently in small magazines. His verses
column7: evolved into writing plays. After receiving an NEA grant
column8: Weaver went on to receive numerous awards
column9: such as the Pew Fellowship in Poetry. His most recent award achievement is the prestigious Kingsley-Tufts Award. Since the early days of getting published
column10: Weaver has authored 12 books of poetry
column12: and two of his plays have been produced. Weaver is now the Alumnae Professor of English at Simmons College.

2016: The Challenge of Interreligious Dialogue in the Age of Laudato Si' at Corcoran Commons

THE BRIEN O'BRIEN AND MARY HASTEN LECTURE IN INTERRELIGIOUS DIALOGUE

column1: There is great potential for deepening interreligious dialogue focusing on our shared ecological challenges. The growing ecological crisis clearly requires the response of science and technology
column2: economics and policy. But we will also need the participation of the world's religious communities as we recognize the moral and spiritual implications of the diminishment of the life support systems of the planet. This talk highlights some of the remarkable work being done within religious communities around the world to bring restoration to people and land. While acknowledging the limitations of religions it also notes the promise for ethical and spiritual transformation regarding ecological attitudes and practices. Interreligious dialogue has a new and vital role to play in healing the Earth.

column1: Mary Evelyn Tucker is senior lecturer and research scholar
column2: and codirector of the Forum on Religion and Ecology

Fifth Annual Dean's Colloquium on Religion and Public Culture

column1: This colloquium takes the form of a conversation about both the content and the style of the papacy of Pope Francis. While Pope Francis has clearly attracted a ready ear among the Catholic faithful
column2: his efforts to present a more compassionate message to bring back to the Church those who have been alienated from the faith has generated a surprising amount of resistance among the hierarchy
column4: who in many respects are his chief critics. The discussion will begin among the panelists who will address these issues
column5: but will move out to include questions and comments from the audience.

2016: "Los Olvidados (The Forgotten)" Art Installation at Devlin Hall

"Los Olvidados (The Forgotten)" is a one-day pop-up installation of work by visual artist Ramiro Gomez documenting service workers' unseen contributions towards maintaining modern American affluence.

This workshop focuses on recent research on teens’ use of social media
column3: with particular attention on the practices of digital technology and how those practices can both support relationships and undermine them. "These paintings were made as meditations on war
column4: specifically the war in Iraq which began in March 2003. The slow
column5: inexorable march to war was unavoidable.  The White House started to beat the drums
column7: and the media related these events in the 24 hours a day news cycle. It became a toxic diatribe full of manipulation and despair. Then
column8: the images of torture taking place
column11: and sickened. The series of Paintings that comprise 24 Hour News grew out of those disclosures.  The terrible arrogance of our leaders seemed dangerously absurd as they expressed terrifyingly diabolical frivolity in the face of such cruelty and destruction. When Donald Rumsfeld said
column13: I knew we were doomed to endure the “farce of arrogance” in its most devastating and destructive power. Thus
column14: the somewhat unfathomable connection between humor
column15: Eros and violence came into the paintings What’s So Funny?.  The images of the tortured and humiliated bodies from the Abu Graib prison exposed the horrifying lack of protection and sanctity for the bodies of the captured and the victims.  Spine  and Half a Brain express that vulnerability. The Lap paintings were an exasperated attempt to put the female point of view into the picture. The Virgin Mary’s Lap
column16: which normally holds such love and tenderness
column17: now holds the wastes of war. With Launch the Virgin’s lap turns from gory reds to celestial blue
column18: symbolizing her removal from the carnage below."

column5: at 10:00 a.m. in Alumni Stadium. Commencement Exercises are a two-part ceremony. column6: graduates and their guests will go to the assigned locations for the individual school/College Diploma Ceremonies at which diplomas are awarded.

2016: Recreating Identity: The Arts and Crafts Movement in Ireland at Burns Library

The Arts and Crafts Movement that first emerged in England in the 1880s took on a distinctive character in Ireland
column3: where its aesthetic and social ideals coalesced around the drive to forge a new national identity. Craft and industrial societies were established under the movement’s aegis to promote handpress printing and bookbinding
column6: and other applied arts. This exhibition complements McMullen Museum’s spring show
column7: “The Arts and Crafts Movement: Making It Irish.”

column2:
2016: The Arts and Crafts Movement: Making it Irish at Devlin Hall

During a year of commemoration of the 1916 Easter Rising
column3: this exhibition offers the first comprehensive examination of the Irish Art and Crafts movement. Like the more familiar Irish Literary Revival
column4: Arts and Crafts practice accompanied and shaped the visual imagination of the country’s transformation from colony to independent nation. As its centerpiece
column5: the exhibition introduces dazzling early medieval-influenced metalwork and embroidered textiles from University College Cork’s Honan Chapel. The collection of this ideologically charged masterpiece of Arts and Crafts achievement
column7: has never before traveled beyond Cork.

column1: The exhibition also features Wilhelmina Geddes’s and Harry Clarke’s stained glass panels that evoke a Celtic and early Christian past
column2: but gesture toward the innovative modernism characterizing the Literary Revival. Other objects on display include handcrafted furniture and metalwork
column4: and jewelry replicating early medieval metalwork. They illustrate both the widespread popular dissemination of Revivalist motifs and the philanthropic promotion of handicraft industries that initiated the Arts and Crafts movement in Ireland.

column1: Major lenders include the National Museum of Ireland
column2: National College of Art and Design

column3: contains essays by scholars from Ireland
column5: and North America. A digital guide to the exhibition has been produced by Joseph Nugent and students in his digital humanities course.

2016: Evolution and the Primacy of Love at Robsham Theater Arts Center

ANNUAL EVELYN UNDERHILL LECTURE IN CHRISTIAN SPIRITUALITY

column1: Teilhard de Chardin held that evolution ushered in a new understanding of reality based on love-energy. This annual lecture explores Teilhard's philosophy of love
column2: the co-relation between love and consciousness in evolution
column3: and the implications of these dynamics for Christian life today.
is Haub Director of Catholic Studies and Visiting Professor at Georgetown University.

column2:
2016: Telling Stories about Women at Corcoran Commons

EIGHTH ANNUAL MARY OF MAGDALA CELEBRATION

column1: This celebration of the feast day of St. Mary of Magdala begins with Mass
column2: followed by lunch and a lecture.  A woman hides yeast; a widow threatens a judge; a woman seeks a coin; wise and foolish virgins await a bridegroom….  The parables can be read as universal teachings about theology or salvation.  They should also be read as reflections of women’s lives

column1: Amy-Jill Levine is University Professor of New Testament and Jewish Studies and E. Rhodes and Leona B. Carpenter Professor of New Testament Studies at Vanderbilt University.

column2:
2016: BC Football in Ireland at Aviva Stadium

Boston College football will open its 2016 season by hosting Georgia Tech in Dublin’s Aviva Stadium on Saturday
column4: in the Aer Lingus College Football Classic. It will be the third time in six years an American college football game will take place in Ireland and the second time BC will play on the Emerald Isle.

column1: Boston College is proud to partner with Anthony Travel in offering numerous travel packages for Eagles fans to choose from. Options range from a four-day
column2: three-night visit to Dublin to a nine-day
column3: eight-night tour of three different cities. There is also a special package for GOLD (Graduates Of the Last Decade) alumni.

column1: While the game is not until next year
column2: tickets are sure to sell out quickly. Secure your travel package by August 15
column4: to receive the best game tickets available! Learn more by visiting www.BC2Ireland.com today.
